title: 114_hr4015
content: The Cardiomyopathy Health Education, Awareness, Risk Assessment, and Training in the Schools (HEARTS) Act of 2015 is aimed at increasing education and awareness of cardiomyopathy among school administrators, educators, and families by providing materials and resources. The Secretary, along with the Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, will develop education materials on cardiomyopathy for school personnel and families, including background information and a risk assessment worksheet. The Secretary will develop guidelines for automated external defibrillators in schools and child care centers, training information on defibrillators and CPR, and recommendations for cardiac emergency response plans. An advisory panel will include representatives from national patient advocacy organizations and medical professionals specializing in cardiomyopathy. The Secretary will collaborate with experts in cardiomyopathy, CDC representatives, and other relevant federal agencies. They will also partner with a national nonprofit advocacy organization. Materials and resources will be disseminated to state educational agencies for distribution. State educational agencies will distribute cardiomyopathy education and awareness materials, risk assessment worksheets, guidelines, training information, and recommendations to school administrators, educators, school health professionals, coaches, parents, guardians, and caregivers. The Secretary will disseminate materials to health departments, pediatricians, hospitals, and other health professionals. The materials will also be posted on the CDC website by the Director. The Secretary will disseminate materials to health departments, pediatricians, hospitals, and other health professionals, as well as post additional information on cardiomyopathy on public Internet websites. State education agencies are encouraged to create webpages dedicated to cardiomyopathy. A report to Congress will be submitted annually on steps taken to increase public education and awareness of cardiomyopathy, defined as a rare heart condition. The rare heart condition, cardiomyopathy, affects the heart muscle and can present with varying symptoms, including no symptoms or progressive symptoms like fatigue, irregular heartbeats, and potential heart failure. Different types of cardiomyopathy include dilated, hypertrophic, restrictive, arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia, and left ventricular noncompaction. The term 'school administrator' refers to a leader in an educational institution, while 'school' encompasses early education programs, child care centers, and elementary or secondary schools. 'National nonprofit advocacy organizations expert in all forms of cardiomyopathy' are organizations providing support services to affected families. National nonprofit advocacy organizations support families affected by cardiomyopathy and fund research to increase awareness and education. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2016, $750,000 for 2017, and $500,000 for each year from 2018 to 2020.
